author: nuno
message:
I think even Qt/QML is going in a similar path, the several platform area going all in different UI/UX paradigms and the user expect them. Think the mantra will be something like write once adapt everywhere retain the core logic.
Making ui's is no longer an exercise of widget/lego. its more of a craftsman work were every pixel is important and every litle animation as a reason.

author: Robert Knight
message:
I've been playing around with React recently coming from a background with Qt. The cool thing about it and what makes it different from the various other 'components for the web' effort is all the possibilities that come out of the functional style where components are essentially functions that take state/properties as input and return a virtual UI tree as output (ie. "renderUI(state, props) -> UI").

As far as cross-platform UI goes, it'll be interesting to see where it ends up. Every approach on the "fully native" to "fully web" spectrum has trade-offs. React/QML are just extra options that sit somewhere along the spectrum.
